columns.text: The goal of this task is to determine the exchange ratio between the two stocks that make the merger terms equivalent to the original merger price of $\$23.13$ per share.

Let's calculate the exchange ratio!
To calculate we have that: 

- Stock price for the offer of $\$23.13$ per share, and;
- The acquirer (Birdie) share price is $\$87$.

Then, by evaluating in $(1)$ we have
$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Exchange ratio} &= \frac{\text{Target share price}}{\text{Acquirer share price}}\\[10pt]
&= \frac{\$23.13}{ \$87}\\[10pt] 
&= 0.27 
\end{align*}
$$


The result is $0.27$. This means Birdie has to issue $0.27$ of its shares for every $1$ share of Hybrid (the Target it plans to acquire).

***LetÂ´s check our result!***

Hybrid has $8$ million stocks, then Birdie would have to issue: $8 \text{ million }\times 0.2659 = 2,126,897 \text{ shares}$.

This offer will be equivalent to a cash: $\$185,040,000 = 2,126,897 \text{ shares}\times \$87$. 

Let's recall the offer of $\$23.13$ per share of Hybrid equals to: $8,000,000 \text{ shares}\times \$23.13= \$185,040,000$

***Our numbers match!***
